introduction: Association of Friends of Technical Science
explore: Explore our projects and learn more about our mission!

home.headline: Promoting Technical Sciences and Innovation
home.subheading: Empowering the next generation of innovators through education, research, and collaboration
home.aboutText: UPTZ brings together enthusiasts, students, and professionals passionate about technology and its applications. Founded in 2020, we aim to make technical knowledge accessible to everyone.
home.projectsSectionDescription: Innovative Solutions by Our Team Members

subsection1.title: Vilson
subsection1.description: Vilson is an advanced electric racing boat that achieved outstanding success at international competitions this year, securing 4th place in the most demanding endurance race and 2nd place in both slalom and elimination races. The vessel is powered by a robust 20kW electric motor and 10kWh Li-Ion battery pack that enables reaching maximum speeds of 25 knots. The construction is reinforced with carbon tubes, and the cockpit design incorporates elements of the Croatian flag with special emphasis on the red and white checkerboard pattern.

subsection2.title: Malo Vitra
subsection2.description: "Malo vitra" is a prototype racing catamaran developed by students as part of the Adria Energy Boat Class project. It's powered by renewable energy sources, utilizing solar cells to drive an electric motor without CO2 emissions. The vessel features a lightweight yet strong carbon fiber composite construction and achieved a top speed of 11.8 knots, showcasing innovative sustainable technology in maritime mobility.

subsection3.title: Teredo Navalis
subsection3.description: "Teredo Navalis" is a solar-powered boat designed and built by students for the Monaco Energy Boat Challenge. Constructed with a lightweight sandwich of styrofoam, PET, carbon, and glass fibers, it achieves a maximum speed of 16 knots using a 1.5 kWh battery pack and 1300 W solar cells, demonstrating sustainable nautical technology.

hydroContest.name: HydroContest
hydroContest.description: An international student competition focused on energy efficiency in sea transport. Teams design and build radio-controlled vessels powered by renewable energy sources.

monacoEnergyBoatChallenge.name: Monaco Energy Boat Challenge
monacoEnergyBoatChallenge.description: A prestigious event where teams from around the world compete with their energy-efficient boats, showcasing innovation in maritime technology.

adriaHydrofoil.name: Adria Hydrofoil
adriaHydrofoil.description: A regional competition promoting the development of hydrofoil technology in the Adriatic region, encouraging students to innovate in marine engineering.

adriaEnergyBoatClass.name: Adria Energy Boat Class
adriaEnergyBoatClass.description: A competition that challenges students to design and build energy-efficient boats, focusing on renewable energy solutions and sustainable maritime practices.

deltaOne.overview: Delta One is our first prototype solar boat designed for the Monaco Energy Boat Challenge competition. Named after its birthplace at Delta 1 (Rowing club Jadran Rijeka), this vessel represents our entry into sustainable maritime racing.

features.feature1: Advanced solar panel array with 1050W total capacity
features.feature2: Lightweight carbon fiber and glass fiber construction
features.feature3: Bluetooth telemetry for real-time energy monitoring

deltaOne.driveSystemDesc: Complete design and construction executed entirely by UPTZ members.

points: Sandwich construction using styrofoam and PET core materials

Lightweight design optimized for solar-powered operation
Precision-formed hull geometry for stable operation at speed

Cable management system for clean installation
Bluetooth telemetry system for real-time monitoring

Modular design allowing for easy maintenance and upgrades

points: Dual MMPT controllers for maximum solar energy harvesting

Real-time energy monitoring via Bluetooth connectivity
Efficient power distribution to minimize energy losses

details.title: Naming Origin & Location
details.description: Delta One was named after its birthplace at Delta 1, the location of Rowing club Jadran Rijeka where the vessel was designed and built. This name reflects both the geographical significance and the pioneering nature of this first prototype in UPTZ's solar boat development program.

details.title: Development Timeline 2020-2021
details.description: The vessel design and development began in 2020 and was successfully completed by the end of June 2021. This intensive year-long project represented UPTZ's first major entry into solar boat technology and sustainable maritime racing, establishing the foundation for future vessel developments.

details.title: Monaco Energy Boat Challenge Entry
details.description: Delta One was developed specifically for participation in the prestigious Monaco Energy Boat Challenge, held under the auspices of Prince Albert II of Monaco. This international competition brings together experts from technical sciences worldwide to design and build vessels of the future powered by renewable energy sources.

details.title: Island of Krk Circumnavigation Test
details.description: The ambitious goal of sailing around the island of Krk (120 miles) was achieved through a methodical six-stage testing program in November 2020. Each stage tested different aspects of the vessel's performance: Rijeka-Glavotok (22km), Glavotok-Krk City (18km), Krk City-Baška (26km), Baška-Vrbnik (22km), Vrbnik-Jadranovo (20km), and Jadranovo-Rijeka (15km).

details.title: Sustainable Maritime Technology
details.description: Delta One represents a breakthrough in zero-emission maritime technology, demonstrating that solar-powered vessels can achieve competitive performance while maintaining complete environmental responsibility. The vessel produces no CO2 emissions during operation and showcases the potential of renewable energy in marine transportation.

details.title: Student-Led Engineering Excellence
details.description: The complete design and construction of Delta One was executed entirely by UPTZ association members, providing invaluable hands-on experience in advanced composite manufacturing, renewable energy systems, and marine vehicle design. This project demonstrates the capabilities of student-led engineering initiatives in cutting-edge technology development.

details.title: Advanced Telemetry Integration
details.description: Delta One features sophisticated Bluetooth-based telemetry systems that provide real-time monitoring of energy consumption and solar panel performance. This data collection capability enables continuous optimization of energy management strategies and provides valuable insights for future vessel improvements.

details.title: Foundation for Future Development
details.description: As UPTZ's first prototype solar vessel, Delta One established the design principles, construction techniques, and performance benchmarks that would inform subsequent projects including Teredo Navalis and other advanced vessels. The experience gained from Delta One's development and testing formed the foundation for UPTZ's continued excellence in sustainable maritime technology.

cockpitConstruction.title: Cockpit Construction
points: Vacuum infusion molding process by Marservis d.o.o. from Kaštelir
Basic laminate: 2 layers of carbon 200 g/m² roving with epoxy resin
Bottom reinforced with Soric XF 135 g/m² sandwich core construction
8 additional layers in cockpit abutment area on carbon tubes
Driver's bulkhead and outer decks with 10mm AIREX T92 PET core
Locally reinforced areas in driver's compartment and battery housing

motorSupport.title: Motor Support
points: Sandwich construction with 25mm thickness for maximum stiffness
PVC core 200 g/m³ with superior structural properties
2 layers of carbon fiber on both inside and outside surfaces
Same carbon fiber grammage as hull for consistency
Bonded to transom using structural adhesive for durability

structuralDesign.title: Structural Design
points: Deck made of 2 layers of carbon fiber with local stiffening
Forward hull and deck bonded with methacrylate-based structural glue
Rear section screwed to aluminum frame with waterproof sealing
Battery and electronics area with specialized joint sealing
Recycled AIREX T92 PET core materials from previous vessels

details.title: Project Overview
details.description: Malo Vitra is our team's latest innovative vessel - a prototype racing catamaran powered entirely by renewable energy sources via solar cells, operating without CO2 emissions. The vessel features an advanced electric propulsion system that supplies power to the outboard electric motor, representing a breakthrough in sustainable maritime technology.

details.title: Competition Performance
details.description: In the Adria Energy Boat Class competition, the Rijeka team achieved outstanding results among 13 international teams. They secured 3rd place on the podium in the most demanding endurance race, 5th place in both slalom and elimination races, finishing 4th overall. This represents the best result in the young team's history, demonstrating exceptional performance in sustainable maritime technology.

details.title: Environmental Impact
details.description: Zero-emission propulsion system with regenerative capabilities. Solar panels provide sustainable energy, making it completely environmentally friendly for marine ecosystems.

details.title: Custom Propeller Design
details.description: The propeller was independently designed and manufactured using additive printing technology with a combination of carbon fiber and nylon at 100% filling density. This innovative propulsion component enabled the vessel to achieve its impressive maximum speed of 11.8 knots, demonstrating the effectiveness of advanced 3D printing in marine applications.

details.title: Team Collaboration
details.description: Developed through interdisciplinary collaboration between naval architecture students, electrical engineers, and composite material specialists from University of Rijeka.

details.title: Technical Challenges
details.description: Overcoming complex hydrodynamic challenges, optimizing battery management systems, and integrating solar charging while maintaining competitive weight limits.

details.title: Future Development
details.description: Plans include implementing autonomous navigation systems, advanced energy management algorithms, and exploring hydrogen fuel cell integration for extended range.

details.title: Academic Research Context
details.description: Adria Energy Boat Class is an interdisciplinary research program combining students, academics, and industry professionals to advance sustainable maritime technology. The initiative focuses on renewable energy integration, electric propulsion systems, and energy storage optimization. Through international competitions, the program bridges theoretical research with practical applications in sustainable marine transportation.

teredoNavalis.overview: Teredo Navalis is a system for monitoring and protecting wooden maritime structures from damaging marine organisms.

hullConstruction.title: Hull & Deck Construction
points: Advanced sandwich construction using styrofoam and PET core materials

compositeWork.title: Composite Manufacturing

Glass fiber outer layers providing impact resistance and UV protection
PET foam core providing structural stiffness while minimizing weight
Vacuum-assisted resin transfer for void-free laminate structure
Post-cure thermal treatment for maximum mechanical properties
Quality control inspection using ultrasonic testing methods

Integrated solar panel mounting points with aerodynamic fairing
Electric motor pod drive system optimized for hydrofoil operation
Telemetry and control systems housed in protected enclosures

Modular construction allowing for maintenance and component access

details.title: Monaco Energy Boat Challenge Participation
details.description: Teredo Navalis represents UPTZ's participation in the prestigious Monaco Solar & Energy Boat Challenge, held under the auspices of Prince Albert II of Monaco. This international competition brings together experts from technical sciences worldwide to design and build vessels of the future powered by renewable energy sources. The competition features three classes (Energy, Solar, and Open) with various racing disciplines including Fleet Race, Slalom Race, and Championship Race.

details.title: Vessel Naming Origin
details.description: The vessel was named 'Teredo Navalis' after the shipworm (Teredo navalis), a marine bivalve mollusk known for boring into wooden ship hulls and marine structures. This naming reflects the vessel's marine engineering focus and pays homage to the historical challenges of maritime construction, while representing the modern solution of advanced composite materials that overcome traditional wood deterioration issues.

details.title: Development Timeline 2021-2022
details.description: The design and construction of Teredo Navalis began in 2021 as the continuation of UPTZ's successful multi-year hydrofoil project 'Adria Hydrofoil'. The vessel development was completed by the end of June 2022, representing an intensive year-long engineering effort by association members. This project marked the second generation of competition vessels, building upon previous experience in international hydrofoil competitions.

details.title: Environmental Impact & Sustainability
details.description: Teredo Navalis exemplifies zero-emission maritime technology, powered exclusively by renewable solar energy with no CO2 emissions during operation. The vessel contributes to the development of energy-sustainable marine transportation, demonstrating that high-performance racing vessels can achieve competitive speeds while maintaining complete environmental responsibility. This aligns with the competition's mission to preserve marine environments and promote clean energy innovation.

details.title: International Engineering Collaboration
details.description: The Monaco Energy Boat Challenge, established in 2014, brings together students and engineers from universities worldwide, along with associations and private companies. UPTZ's participation represents Croatia's contribution to this global initiative for developing alternative propulsion systems and advancing hydro-wing technology. The competition serves as a platform for international knowledge exchange and collaborative innovation in sustainable maritime engineering.

details.title: Technical Innovation Focus
details.description: The project emphasizes development of new vessel forms, advancement of hydrofoil technology, and implementation of alternative propulsion systems using exclusively ecological energy sources. Teredo Navalis incorporates cutting-edge telemetry systems for real-time monitoring of energy consumption and solar panel performance via 5G connectivity, representing the integration of IoT technology in competitive sailing.

details.title: Student-Led Engineering Excellence
details.description: Teredo Navalis demonstrates the capabilities of student-led engineering projects, with complete design and construction executed entirely by UPTZ association members. This hands-on approach provides invaluable practical experience in advanced composite manufacturing, renewable energy systems integration, and high-performance marine vehicle design, preparing students for careers in sustainable maritime technology.

details.title: Future of Sustainable Racing
details.description: As the main project of UPTZ for 2021-2022, Teredo Navalis represents the future direction of competitive sailing toward sustainable technologies. The vessel serves as a testing platform for renewable energy integration, energy-efficient hull design, and advanced materials application, contributing valuable data and experience for the broader adoption of clean energy solutions in marine transportation.

teredoNavalis.technical: This project combines advanced vibration detection sensors, waterproof computing systems, and specialized coatings for protecting wooden structures in marine environments.

Longitudinal reinforcement with two carbon tubes (50mm outer diameter)
Carbon tube wall thickness of 2mm for optimal strength-to-weight ratio
Croatian flag elements integrated into exterior cockpit design
Red checkerboard pattern emphasizing national identity and pride

motorSupport.title: Engine Mount & Propulsion

High strength construction combining advanced composite materials
Waterjet-cut components for precision manufacturing
Prepreg materials molded parts for optimal quality

Hydraulic steering system with steering wheel control

details.title: Project Overview
details.description: Vilson is our advanced electric racing boat that represents a breakthrough in sustainable marine technology. With its closed-type cockpit design and integrated Croatian flag elements, it combines performance with national identity. The vessel achieved remarkable success in international competitions, demonstrating the effectiveness of electric propulsion in competitive maritime environments.

details.title: Competition Performance
details.description: This year, the team from Rijeka reached 4th place in the most demanding endurance race, while they achieved 2nd place in the slalom race and the elimination race, which made them get onto the podium in 2nd place. 17 teams from all over the world took part in the competition, and their placement is also the best result of this young team.

details.title: Environmental Impact
details.description: Powered entirely by electric propulsion with Li-Ion battery technology, Vilson operates with zero direct emissions. The vessel demonstrates that high-performance racing can be achieved sustainably, paving the way for cleaner marine transportation technologies.

details.title: Innovation Features
details.description: Vilson incorporates cutting-edge carbon fiber sandwich construction, precision waterjet-cut components, and advanced prepreg materials. The integration of hydraulic steering with electric propulsion represents a significant advancement in marine control systems.

details.title: Cultural Design
details.description: The exterior cockpit design incorporates elements of the Croatian national flag with special emphasis on the red checkerboard pattern. This design reflects national pride and identity through modern and dynamic aesthetics, making Vilson a true ambassador of Croatian engineering excellence.

details.title: Team Collaboration
details.description: Developed through intensive collaboration between naval architecture students, electrical engineers, and composite material specialists. The project brought together expertise from multiple disciplines to create a world-class racing vessel.

details.title: Technical Excellence
details.description: Advanced manufacturing techniques including vacuum infusion and oven-cured prepregs ensure optimal structural integrity. The longitudinal carbon tube reinforcement and specialized battery compartment design represent engineering innovation at its finest.

details.title: Future Development
details.description: Plans include exploring advanced battery management systems, regenerative charging capabilities, and further optimization of the hull design for even better racing performance while maintaining environmental sustainability.

vilson.technical: The robot uses GPS-free navigation systems, highly durable materials, and specialized algorithms for natural pattern recognition.

hydroContest.overview: HydroContest is the first international student competition and incubator of ideas devoted to energy efficiency in sea transport. Teams have a task to independently design and build a radio-controlled vessel powered by renewable energy sources.

competitionRules.title: Competition Requirements
points: Vessel dimensions must fit within 2.5m × 2.5m × 2m volume
Maximum engine power limited to 1.4kW for fair competition
Radio-controlled operation with autonomous design freedom
Three disciplines: 20kg passenger, 200kg freight, 1-hour endurance
Teams must include manager, logistics, and communication roles
Design and performance completely left to team innovation

constructionApproach.title: UPTZ Construction Method
points: Carbon/Kevlar sandwich construction for lightweight performance
Vessel dimensions: 3.65m length × 0.7m width
Total weight 32kg without load for optimal efficiency
Priority focus on heavyweight transport vessel design
Advanced composite materials for strength-to-weight optimization
Hydrodynamic design improvements for reduced energy consumption

sustainabilityFocus.title: Environmental Innovation
points: Emphasis on electric propulsion and hydrofoil technology
Alternative energy sources and energy-efficient systems
Addressing maritime pollution (90% international trade via ships)
Annual CO2 reduction goal (120 million tons from sea transport)
Innovation in economically viable environmental protection
Development of sustainable maritime transportation solutions

details.title: Competition Overview
details.description: HydroContest is the first international student competition and incubator of ideas devoted to energy efficiency in sea transport. This innovative competition brings together students from universities worldwide to independently design and build radio-controlled vessels powered by renewable energy sources, fostering innovation in maritime technology.

details.title: Environmental Motivation
details.description: The competition addresses critical environmental challenges: approximately 90% of international trade occurs via maritime transport, with sea shipping annually releasing 120 million tons of CO2 into the atmosphere. One tanker engine launch pollutes equivalent to 15,000 cars simultaneously, making sustainable maritime innovation essential for our planet's future.

details.title: Three Competition Disciplines
details.description: The competition features three distinct disciplines representing future transportation improvements: Transport of Passengers (20kg lightweight), Freight Transport (200kg heavyweight), and Continuous Driving Without Recharging (1-hour endurance race). Each discipline tests different aspects of energy efficiency and vessel design optimization.

details.title: Technical Innovation Focus
details.description: HydroContest emphasizes innovation in shipbuilding and maritime affairs, particularly electric propulsion and hydrofoil technology. The competition promotes development of new vessel forms, alternative propulsion systems using ecological energy sources, and economically viable solutions that contribute to environmental protection and CO2 emission reduction.

details.title: UPTZ Competition History
details.description: UPTZ achieved remarkable success with 3rd place in the 2018 HydroContest held in St. Tropez, France, competing against 32 universities worldwide. The team's vessel was specifically designed for heavyweight transport, demonstrating Croatian engineering excellence in sustainable maritime technology on the international stage.

details.title: Current Project Development
details.description: UPTZ's current vessel measures 3.65m in length and 0.7m in width, weighing 32kg without load. The lightweight design is achieved through carbon/Kevlar sandwich construction, prioritizing heavyweight transport capability. Future plans include improving hydrodynamics, reducing energy consumption, and aiming for top-five placement in upcoming competitions.

details.title: Team Structure & Collaboration
details.description: According to competition rules, each team must have designated roles including a manager, members responsible for logistics and communication, with other functions assigned based on team needs and capabilities. This structure promotes interdisciplinary collaboration and project management skills among participating students.

details.title: Knowledge Transfer & Education
details.description: The project serves as a platform for sharing acquired knowledge and experience from previous competitions with new members, building upon collective expertise. This educational approach ensures continuous improvement and knowledge preservation within the UPTZ association while fostering next-generation maritime engineers.

contact.reachOut: Feel free to reach out with any questions or inquiries. We're here to help!

aboutUs.heroDescription: We are the Association of Applied Technical Sciences (UPTZ), a team of young engineers, students and enthusiasts from Rijeka, founded in 2018, united by our love for innovation and applied technical sciences. Our members come from various fields, including the Faculty of Maritime Studies in Rijeka, and together we work on projects that combine theory and practice.

team.title: Our Team
team.description: Meet the dedicated individuals who make our projects possible. Our team is organized into specialized divisions, each contributing their unique expertise to advance maritime engineering and innovation.

projectManagers.title: Project Managers
projectManagers.description: Strategic leaders who coordinate projects and ensure successful delivery of our initiatives.

manufacturing.title: Engineering Team
manufacturing.description: Skilled engineers who bring our designs to life using advanced materials and construction techniques.

electrical.title: Electrical Team
electrical.description: Electrical engineers specializing in power systems, control electronics, and energy management.

development.title: Development Team
development.description: Software developers and engineers creating innovative solutions and control systems.

marketing.title: Marketing and Web
marketing.description: Creative professionals managing our digital presence and community outreach.

volunteers.title: Volunteers
volunteers.description: Passionate supporters who contribute their time and skills to various project activities.

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.description: Our mission is to promote technical sciences and innovation through education, research, and collaboration. We aim to make technical knowledge accessible to everyone, regardless of their background.

vision.title: Our Vision
vision.description: We envision a future where technical knowledge is shared freely and openly, enabling individuals and communities to solve problems and create innovative solutions to global challenges.

history.title: Our History
history.description: Founded in 2020, UPTZ began as a small group of enthusiasts with a shared passion for technology and education. Since then, we've grown into a diverse community of students, professionals, and hobbyists working together on exciting projects.

partners.heroDescription: Our partners are key pillars of our success, enabling us to push the boundaries of maritime engineering.

introduction.title: Our Open Source Philosophy
introduction.description: We believe in the power of open source to drive innovation and collaboration. By sharing our work openly, we contribute to the global community of knowledge and enable others to build upon our foundations.

contribute.title: How to Contribute
contribute.description: We welcome contributions from developers, designers, and anyone interested in our projects. Whether you're fixing a bug, improving documentation, or adding new features, your contributions help make our projects better.
contribute.getInTouch: Interested in contributing but not sure where to start? Get in touch with us!

electricBicycle.title: Self-construction of electric bicycle
electricBicycle.author: Mislav Selec, graduate in electrical engineering

footer.description: UPTZ brings together enthusiasts, students, and professionals passionate about technology and its applications. We make technical knowledge accessible to everyone.
footer.socialDescription: Stay connected with us on social media for updates and news.
footer.donationDescription: The money raised by donations covers the cost of components for our boat. Even a small gesture is a great help to our team.
footer.donationNote: Your support helps fund our projects and educational initiatives.
